outcome_measures.name: Quality of life
outcome_measures.description: Will be assessed using both global sense and disease specific measures including the satisfaction with life scale, the Short Form-12, and the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Breast. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Balance
outcome_measures.description: Will estimate standing and reaching balance using a balance plate. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Body composition
outcome_measures.description: Will be assessed using dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) for all outcome measures. The DEXA scans were used to determine total body composition including bone-mineral density, as well as, percentage body fat and fat-free mass for all body regions. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Adherence
outcome_measures.description: Will be defined via attendance at prescribed sessions and will be assessed using exercise logs, upon which participants will record all exercise performed at the center or independently. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Self-reported physical function
outcome_measures.description: Will be measured with the abbreviated Late-Life Function and Disability Inventory. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Objective functional performance
outcome_measures.description: Will be assessed using 3 valid and reliable timed performance-related mobility tasks: 400-meter walk (the primary outcome), stair-climb, and lift and carry task. Assessments of Mobility-Related Self-Efficacy to complete each functional task will also be completed with the tests. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Body weight
outcome_measures.description: Will be measured to the nearest 0.1 kilogram using a calibrated and certified balance beam scale. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Muscular strength
outcome_measures.description: Will be assessed using standardized one-repetition maximum testing protocols for the chest press and leg extension exercises. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Feasibility
outcome_measures.description: Descriptive statistics for assessments of recruitment rates, adverse events, and retention rates will be calculated prospectively throughout the trial. Feasibility assessments of participants’ satisfaction with the exercise and dietary intervention will also be completed at the end of the 24-week intervention. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Mobility disability
outcome_measures.description: Assessed with the 400-meter walk test. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the last observation carried forward (LOCF) approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

outcome_measures.name: Fatigue
outcome_measures.description: Will be assessed with the Brief Fatigue Inventory. Will be analyzed using paired samples t-tests. Statistical significance will be assumed at p =< 0.05, and results will be based on two-tailed statistical tests. Mean change from baseline, paired sample t-test, and effect size estimates will be calculated for each outcome measure. Analyses will be conducted using the intent-to-treat principle to account for missing data with the LOCF approach, used to impute change across time to be zero. Additionally, effect sizes (Cohen’s d) will be calculated by taking the mean difference and dividing by the pooled standard deviation to determine the magnitude of differences observed for each outcome.

trials.brief_title: Exercise and Diet Counseling Program in Improving Quality of Life in Stage I-III Breast Cancer Survivors
trials.official_title: Healthy New Albany: Breast Cancer Project
trials.brief_summary: This trial studies the benefits of an exercise and diet counseling program in improving quality of life in stage I-III breast cancer survivors. Exercise and diet counseling may help improve weight loss and relevant clinical and patient-reported outcomes in overweight or obese breast cancer survivors.
trials.detail_description:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To determine the feasibility of delivering a community-based, comprehensive lifestyle weight management (LWM) intervention to 20 overweight or obese breast cancer (BC) survivors.
II. Explore preliminary efficacy of the community-based, comprehensive LWM intervention for producing meaningful improvements in select clinically-relevant anthropometric, fitness, functional, and patient-reported outcomes in BC survivors.
III. Provide the effect size estimates necessary to inform the design of a subsequent R01 application addressing a large scale, optimally powered, randomized controlled, community-based LWM comparative efficacy intervention trial targeting weight loss in BC survivors.

OUTLINE:
Patients undergo aerobic exercise over 10-30 minutes and resistance exercise comprising 1-3 sets of 8-12 repetitions of 10 different exercises over 1 hour for 24 weeks. Patients also receive behavioral activity counseling once a week and nutritional counseling over 30 minutes for 10 sessions after center-based exercise sessions during months 1-2.

After completion of study, patients are followed up at 3 and 6 months.

unstructured.description: Female breast cancer (stage I-III), within (w/in) 60 months after cessation of active treatment (surgery, chemotherapy, radiation), and may be on continued hormone therapy.
Overweight/obese (body mass index [BMI] > 25).
Ability to understand and the willingness to sign a written informed consent.
Willing and physically able to participate in physical activity.
Obtain physician consent via primary care physician and/or treating oncologist.
> 60 months post breast cancer therapy.
Contraindications to exercise.
Diagnosis of cancer other than breast that is receiving active treatment.
Currently receiving chemotherapy/radiation.
Musculoskeletal/neurological disorder inhibiting them from safe exercise.
Pregnant or nursing women.
Unable to give informed consent.

arms.arm_description: Patients undergo aerobic exercise over 10-30 minutes and resistance exercise comprising 1-3 sets of 8-12 repetitions of 10 different exercises over 1 hour for 24 weeks. Patients also receive behavioral activity counseling once a week and nutritional counseling over 30 minutes for 10 sessions after center-based exercise sessions during months 1-2.

outcome_measures.name: Smoking and alcohol use
outcome_measures.description: Smoking and alcohol use will be evaluated using items selected from the prior cohort study of young women with breast cancer and our prior Smoke Free Study.

outcome_measures.name: Socio-demographics
outcome_measures.description: Women will be asked about their race, education, employment and financial status using items selected from the Alliance Patient Questionnaire that is currently being piloted (Alliance A191401), adapted to include an item on employment status that has been tested previously in a breast cancer population and is going to be added to the next version of the Alliance Patient Questionnaire.

outcome_measures.name: Financial burden
outcome_measures.description: Will use items adapted from the National Health Interview Survey and the Cancer Outcomes Research and Surveillance (CanCORS) Caregiver Study to assess financial burden and to estimate out of pocket expenses attributed to their breast cancer diagnosis.

outcome_measures.name: Self-care
outcome_measures.description: The EQ-5D-5L will be used to generate and evaluate QALYs.

outcome_measures.name: Vaginal dryness
outcome_measures.description: Will use the 1 item regarding vaginal dryness on the Breast Cancer Prevention Trial (BCPT) and will group moderate, quite a bit, extreme responses to define the vaginal dryness rate at 1 year.

outcome_measures.name: Usual activities
outcome_measures.description: The EQ-5D-5L will be used to generate and evaluate QALYs.

outcome_measures.name: Adherence to hormonal or other oral therapy
outcome_measures.description: Measurement of adherence to oral therapy using a 10 item self-report medication adherence measure based on work from Voils et al. among women who report currently prescribed oral hormonal or other oral therapy.

outcome_measures.name: Anxiety and depression
outcome_measures.description: The Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) will be used to evaluate for clinically significant depression.

outcome_measures.name: Emotional Symptoms
outcome_measures.description: Anxiety and depression will be measured by the 14-item Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS).

outcome_measures.name: Mobility
outcome_measures.description: The European Quality of Life Five Dimension Five Level Scale Questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) will be used to generate and evaluate quality-adjusted life years (QALYs).

outcome_measures.name: Adolescent and young adult (AYA) concerns
outcome_measures.description: AYA concerns will be measured by 14 items from the AYA HOPE Study follow-up questionnaire that ask patients to rate their level of concern regarding a range of AYA survivorship-focused issues, including fertility, diet and nutrition, physical activity, weight management, survivorship care, recurrence concerns, and financial concerns, and we have added genetics and body image. 3 items have been added to the AYA concerns that ask about the desire for additional information about select issues facing young women with breast cancer including about body image/beauty, smoking, and alcohol consumption.

outcome_measures.name: Pain and discomfort
outcome_measures.description: The EQ-5D-5L will be used to generate and evaluate QALYs.

outcome_measures.name: Overall symptoms
outcome_measures.description: The Patient-Reported Outcomes Version of the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (PRO-CTCAE) is a patient-centered, standardized self-report measure that enables patients to report symptoms and adverse events (AEs). The PRO-CTCAE has demonstrated favorable validity, reliability, and responsiveness in a large heterogeneous United States sample of cancer patients undergoing treatment. 40 PRO-CTCAE items that are salient to young women with breast cancer will be collected. The PRO-CTCAE items use conditional branching for AEs that contain multiple attributes. A modified 19-item version of the Breast Cancer Prevention Trial (BCPT) Symptom Checklist will evaluate common symptoms, including hot flashes, fatigue, sexual problems, and musculoskeletal complaints. The Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) 8-item Fatigue Scale will be used to assess fatigue.

outcome_measures.name: Physical activity
outcome_measures.description: Physical activity will be assessed using a modified version of the Godin Leisure-Time Exercise Questionnaire (GLTEQ). This self-reported measure is used to estimate weekly frequencies of strenuous, moderate, and light activities. It has been modified to include average duration of activities. Weekly minutes of moderate and vigorous activity (MVPA) will be the main measure of physical activity; however weekly minutes of vigorous activity (MVA) and the average weekly frequency of mild, moderate and strenuous intensity exercise based on the Leisure Score Index (LSI) will also be examined to evaluate change in physical activity behaviors. The Godin measure will be administered at multiple timepoints and will be used to evaluate change in physical activity over time.

trials.brief_title: An Internet-Based Intervention (Young, Empowered, and Strong) for the Monitoring of Symptoms and Behavior in Patients with Stage 0-IV Breast Cancer, YES Study
trials.official_title: Young, Empowered, & Strong (YES): The Young Women's Breast Cancer Study 2- Focus on Newly Diagnosed / Metastatic Intervention
trials.brief_summary: This phase II trial investigates how well an internet-based portal called Young, Empowered, and Strong (YES) works in monitoring symptoms and behavior in patients with stage 0-IV breast cancer. The YES portal is designed to help monitor cancer related issues and to share self-management information and resources to those interested in particular issues or who score high enough on the symptom measures designed to assess and track noticeable symptoms (and thus might benefit from such), as well as to share potential research opportunities when available. The portal is also designed to create a community among these participants through the yeschat.org discussion board. The YES portal may provide information to support patients with breast cancer through and beyond treatment and serve as a platform for future recruitment to clinical studies and supportive care opportunities.
trials.detail_description:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To characterize the disease and psychosocial state of young women with newly diagnosed breast cancer shortly after diagnosis and in follow-up, as well as among young women living with metastatic disease throughout the course of their care. (Prospective Cohort)
II. To evaluate symptoms/concerns and quality of life over time as well as additional aspects of the experience of breast cancer for young women. (Prospective Cohort)
III. To collect tumor and blood specimens to characterize the tumors, and bank for future studies. (Prospective Cohort)
IV. To test the effect of proactive versus (vs.) reactive delivery of sexual health self-management resources through the YES portal. (Embedded Phase II randomized control trial [RCT])

OUTLINE: Patients are randomized to 1 of 4 arms.

ARM A (NEWLY DIAGNOSED): Patients automatically receive sexual health and vaginal dryness symptom information sheets in their portal. Patients also complete serial monitoring assessments over 10-15 minutes once weekly (QW) for 12 weeks, then once monthly for 1 year. Patients may opt in to use the portal for 5 additional years.

ARM B (NEWLY DIAGNOSED): Patients receive the sexual health and vaginal dryness symptom information sheets in their portal only if they trigger them based off of their survey responses. Patients also complete serial monitoring assessments over 10-15 minutes QW for 12 weeks, then once monthly for 1 year. Patients may opt in to use the portal for 5 additional years.

ARM C (METASTATIC): Patients automatically receive sexual health and vaginal dryness symptom information sheets in their portal. Patients also complete serial monitoring assessments over 10-15 minutes QW for 12 weeks, then once monthly for 1 year. Patients may opt in to use the portal for 5 additional years.

ARM D (METASTATIC): Patients receive the sexual health and vaginal dryness symptom information sheets in their portal only if they trigger them based off of their survey responses. Patients also complete serial monitoring assessments over 10-15 minutes QW for 12 weeks, then once monthly for 1 year. Patients may opt in to use the portal for 5 additional years.

After randomization, patients are followed up every 6 months for 3 years, then annually for 2 years.

unstructured.description: STAGE 0-3: Diagnosed with breast cancer

STAGE 0-3: Less than 3 months post diagnosis date of new primary or local recurrence (prior history of other cancer is allowed as long as treated with curative intent and no evidence of disease from that cancer)
STAGE 0-3: Has not started treatment for breast cancer diagnosis yet
STAGE 0-3: Is planning to get care at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI)
STAGE 0-3: Be fluent in and able to read English
STAGE 0-3: Have internet access on a regular basis at the time of consent that can support the web-based platform
STAGE IV: Initial diagnosis of breast cancer
STAGE IV: Be fluent in and able to read English
STAGE IV: Have internet access on a regular basis at the time of consent that can support the web-based platform
